author: Lyam Lavigne
title: 8 Enormous Thrift Stores In California That Bargain Hunters Swear Are Better Than Costco
text:
Searching for enormous thrift stores in California that rival warehouse clubs for amazing deals?
These 8 mammoth secondhand shops offer incredible bargains and unique treasures that even Costco can’t match!
1. Savers (Arcadia)
Savers in Arcadia is the thrift store equivalent of that friend who’s impossibly organized.
Everything has its place, which means less time hunting and more time finding.
Their furniture department showcases pieces that look like they just stepped out of a home magazine.
You might spot a leather armchair that costs less than the takeout you ordered last weekend.
The color-coded tag system turns shopping into a treasure hunt with extra rewards.
Tuesday’s blue tags might be 50% off, making that already affordable dresser practically free.
They test all electronics before they hit the floor – no bringing home mystery appliances.
The store layout flows logically from room to room, like walking through someone’s well-designed home.
Their lamp selection could illuminate a small country, with styles from classic to wonderfully weird.
Weekend shoppers arrive early, armed with coffee and determination.
The staff actually remembers regular customers, creating a neighborhood feel despite the store’s size.
They restock throughout the day, giving afternoon shoppers a fighting chance at finding treasures.
Bring a friend for second opinions – and to help you haul that perfect couch to your car.
Where: 16 E Live Oak Ave, Arcadia, CA 91006
2. Goodwill Wholesale Outlet (Oxnard)
This place is so huge you might need breadcrumbs to find your way back to the entrance.
The Goodwill Wholesale Outlet in Oxnard isn’t playing around when it comes to size or selection.
It’s like someone took a regular thrift store and gave it superhero serum.
The furniture section alone could outfit a small apartment building.
You’ll discover couches with personality that cost less than a fancy dinner for two.
Bookshelves that have held everything from classic literature to someone’s prized snow globe collection.
Dining tables where families have shared countless meals, now ready for your family stories.
The constant rotation of merchandise means Monday’s store is completely different from Friday’s.
They organize by category, saving you from the “needle in a haystack” experience of smaller shops.
Bring measurements of your doorways – nothing worse than finding the perfect piece that won’t fit through your front door.
The staff knows their inventory and can point you toward recent arrivals.
Early birds definitely catch the worm here – the best pieces vanish faster than donuts in an office break room.
The warehouse setting means no fancy lighting or staged displays – just honest-to-goodness bargains.
Where: 1401 N Rice Ave, Oxnard, CA 93030
3. Habitat for Humanity of Greater Los Angeles ReStore (Los Angeles)
Shopping at the ReStore feels like doing good while doing well for yourself.
Every purchase helps build homes for families in need – furniture karma at its finest.
The selection ranges from basic starter pieces to items that would make interior designers swoon.
You might find brand-new kitchen cabinets donated from a remodeling project.
Their appliance section features refrigerators, stoves, and washers that have plenty of life left.
The inventory comes from both individual donors and corporate partnerships.
This means you might score items that stores couldn’t sell due to minor packaging damage.
The staff knows the story behind many unique pieces and shares them enthusiastically.
DIY enthusiasts will lose their minds over the building materials section.
They offer delivery services for larger items, saving you from renting a truck or bribing friends.
The store layout groups similar items together, making it easy to compare options.
Professional flippers and designers shop here regularly – a testament to the quality and prices.
Special sales throughout the month offer additional discounts on already reasonable prices.
The bright, organized space makes treasure hunting feel less like work and more like adventure.
Where: 1071 S La Brea Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90019
4. Goodwill Southern California Outlet Store (Los Angeles)
This isn’t just thrift shopping – it’s an extreme sport with furniture as the prize.
The Goodwill Outlet operates on a completely different model than regular thrift stores.
Items are sold by weight, which means that solid wood bookcase might cost less than your morning latte.
At first glance, the place looks like organized chaos – because that’s exactly what it is.
Bins and tables overflow with potential treasures waiting for someone with vision to discover them.
The furniture section features everything from basic chairs to conversation pieces with history.
The inventory changes completely throughout the day as new bins roll out.
Dedicated bargain hunters arrive when doors open and stay for multiple rotations.
You might find a perfectly good desk for the price of a fast-food meal.
Bring gloves if you plan to dig deep – this is hands-on treasure hunting at its most intense.
The community of regular shoppers has unwritten rules about bin etiquette.
Be respectful and you might get insider tips on when the best furniture typically appears.
This place isn’t for shoppers who need pristine retail environments.
The café inside provides necessary fuel for your bargain marathon.
Where: 3150 N San Fernando Rd, Los Angeles, CA 90065
5. The Salvation Army Thrift Store & Donation Center (Pasadena)
The Salvation Army store stands like a thrifting landmark in Pasadena.
Their furniture section dominates the space, showcasing their commitment to home essentials.
You’ll find everything from basic starter pieces to antiques with stories to tell.
The prices seem like they’re from a different decade – in the best possible way.
A complete dining set might cost less than a single chair at a regular furniture store.
They test all electronics and appliances, so no bringing home expensive paperweights.
The staff actually helps load purchases – a small courtesy that makes a big difference.
Their discount system means additional savings on already reasonable prices.
Monday mornings feature weekend donations, making it prime time for furniture hunting.
The store layout groups similar items together, creating natural browsing sections.
They’re particularly good for solid wood pieces that would cost a fortune new.
The distinctive red awning welcomes shoppers from all walks of life.
Your purchases support community programs, adding purpose to your bargain hunting.
The friendly atmosphere makes newcomers feel as welcome as regular shoppers.
Where: 56 W Del Mar Blvd, Pasadena, CA 91105
6. Goodwill Auction & Outlet Store (Long Beach)
This place turns furniture shopping into a competitive sport – and it’s absolutely thrilling.
The auction format creates an atmosphere of excitement you won’t find at regular thrift stores.
Items are displayed for preview before bidding begins, building anticipation.
You might spot a sectional sofa that would cost thousands new going for pocket change.
The auctions happen daily, drawing a crowd of regulars who know the ropes.
First-timers should arrive early to register and study the merchandise before bidding starts.
The auctioneer keeps things moving at a pace that’s both exhilarating and slightly intimidating.
Bidding often starts at just $5 for substantial pieces of furniture.
The warehouse setting isn’t fancy, but that’s why the prices are so incredible.
You’ll see everything from basic starter furniture to vintage pieces with serious character.
Regulars develop strategies like bidding on less popular items or coming on slower weekdays.
The staff can help load your victories, but bringing your own muscle is wise for larger items.
The blue bins outside contain additional treasures sold by weight rather than auction.
The daily rotation means every visit offers completely different opportunities.
Where: 646 W Esther St, Long Beach, CA 90813
7. Out of the Closet – Glassell Park (Los Angeles)
The bright pink building stands out like a flamingo at a penguin convention.
Out of the Closet combines bargain hunting with a mission – supporting HIV services and testing.
Their furniture section might be more curated than massive, but quality trumps quantity here.
You’ll find pieces with personality that don’t require a second mortgage to purchase.
The store has a thoughtfully organized feel, unlike the chaos of some larger thrift operations.
Mid-century pieces appear regularly, often at prices that would make vintage dealers sob with envy.
The staff clearly believes in both the merchandise and the mission behind the store.
They offer free HIV testing on-site, making this thrift store truly unique in its community impact.
The brick building with vibrant pink accents is impossible to miss from the street.
Weekend visits often reveal newly donated treasures from spring cleaning projects.
Their furniture turnover happens quickly, so regular visits increase your chances of finding something special.
The store layout makes browsing efficient, unlike the labyrinthine experience at some thrift shops.
They clean and inspect furniture before it hits the floor, so no unpleasant surprises.
The pharmacy inside makes this a truly unique one-stop shopping experience.
Where: 2425 N San Fernando Rd, Los Angeles, CA 90065
8. Goodwill Industries Sacramento Valley & Northern Nevada (Sacramento)
This Sacramento Goodwill location is the aircraft carrier of thrift stores – massive and impressive.
The building houses furniture displayed in room-like settings that spark imagination.
Their selection ranges from basic starter pieces to items that look straight from a designer showroom.
The prices make you check twice to make sure you’re reading the tags correctly.
A complete bedroom set might cost less than a night in a decent hotel.
The staff organizes by style and function, creating natural shopping zones.
They test all electronics and appliances before they hit the sales floor.
The American flag flies proudly outside this community institution.
New items appear throughout the day, giving all shoppers a chance at finding treasures.
Their color tag system means additional discounts on certain days of the week.
The bright blue signage makes this location impossible to miss from the road.
Weekend warriors arrive early, ready to claim the best pieces before others discover them.
They offer delivery options for larger purchases, saving your back and your friendships.
The store supports job training programs, so your bargain hunting directly helps the community.
Where: 2040 Alta Arden Expy, Sacramento, CA 95825
California’s thrift scene proves that one person’s castoffs become another’s treasures.
With patience, vision, and these eight massive stores, you’ll furnish your home for less than the cost of a designer coffee table!
